Overall the food quality was decent but it is a little on the pricier side of things. I'd come back if i'm in the area and definitely would tell friends to try.
author: Kevin W.

description: I've been wanting to try their beef noodle soup for a while. So my dinner option was obvious when I saw HoDaLa on UberEats. I ordered the Spice Braised Beef Noodle Soup and the Beef Wrap. The Beef Noodle Soup seemed a bit smaller than expected, but it ended up being pretty filling. The broth was super flavorful and just mildly spicy. The beef was tender and savory. It was a pretty dam satisfying bowl of Taiwanese beef noodle soup! The beef wrap is just as tasty and not too greasy. That dipping sauce is amazing, like now I wanna put it on everything. Delicious!
author: Nana L.

description: Went twice in a week. Good stuff! Dessert is really good. Will be back for sure and will try my 3rd soup at that time.
author: Jeff D.

description: First time here and it was definitely a good experience,the restaurant was packed around 6:30 to 7pm...the bao's are definitely worth trying the bf and I got a trio of bao's pork belly/fried chicken/kimchi pork belly all were tasty and bao it self was just right in texture and taste...we both opt for the sizzling plates meat lovers and surf and turf, the pepper mushroom spaghetti was really good..the meat and the sausage I had were tasty and cooked just right..the surf and turf had squid and steak which my bf said tasted good...and you have to wash it down with some beer,after hodala means bottoms up in Taiwanese I was told
author: jonathan h.

description: Pork blood cake and tw beer is not bad ! 鐵板麵還好，牛牛腩飯is pretty good . They have those pic sign for fun and the decoration is full of memory !!!!!
author: Jill L.

description:
Solid food, the noodle soup was good. I enjoyed the texture of the noodle, flavor of the soup and tenderness of the beef. Popcorn chicken was good but it's more like your standard fare Asian popcorn chicken you can get anywhere. It is executed perfectly and was tasty but small portion for $6.99.

Would like to see the intestine dog (aka big sausage wrap small sausage) and stinky tofu as they are Taiwanese staples.
author: Cecile X.

description: I really like their pork ribs!!!! I would like to see ground pork and pickled veggies over noodles. great place to have lunch.
author: DiaMan L.

description: Food and ambiance is great. The food has a bit of excess of pepper for my taste, but otherwise delicious!!
author: Carol T.

description:
This is our first time trying this place out. From the pictures the dishes look delicious. The decor and the ambiance feels like we are in a cozy shop in Taiwan . The seatings that they have are refurbished movie chair seats and the stools are of refurbished steel pipes. The lightings are cool too. They use the old Edison style bulbs. 

This place so far is quite quaint!
author: Sol P.

description:
Can't believe Chicken'licious already closed down and this opened. Then again Turtle Tower being right across the street can be hard to beat. 

First off, very nice choice of decors to the ambience and even down to the details of furniture choice. Kind of a rustic modernized twist, from those 2 Star war and iron man figurine posters at the door to the dim light Taiwanese night market looking stand at the entrance with many candies and snacks to choose from. Seems like a cozy appealing place to step into for a cold windy night with some warm food. First thing I noticed were the water cups. They're silver and bronze version of our typical red party cups haha, brownie points. 

Now what I actually tried were their Taiwanese pork belly bao, fried spicy chicken wings, squid and steak pasta, and their beef noodle soup. 

Taiwanese pork belly bao might be gimmicky but get it! Won't disappoint! Tender juice thick pork belly on the inside, very nice pairing, on point. 

Fried chicken wings, meh they were ok. To me more flavors were on the outside and the inside were pretty bland. 

Squid and steak pasta.... where do I even begin with you. First of all maybe you guys should cut that up for us because it was annoying cutting that whole squid on your own. Plus it kind of ruin the presentation because it just looked like a sizzling plate of pasta with the grilled squid slapped on top. Taste wise, I would past.

Biggest past up I would give it to the beef noodle soup. You would think with a Taiwanese theme restaurant this would be safe. NOPE. It was definitely on more of the tomato side of things... tasted like those tomato vegetable can soup and you just add in noodles and beef. The beef were done nicely though, I give it that. 

Can't tell if we were just trying the wrong things or everything we ordered was just not up to par. Maybe I'll give the braised pork over rice a try the next time I decide to go there.
author: Aly C.

description: I like their Taiwanese pork belly gua bao. It's very authentic with a lot of peanuts powder. Their fried chicken cutlet is also very crispy and juicy. I wish they will add oyster pancake to their menu.
author: Steffi H.

description:
Some of the negative reviews have the right idea.  Post a bad review, shop gets less crowded, come back for more.  I wish I could give it 1 star, but I just can't bring myself to do it.  

As a Taiwanese person, everything on the menu is something my mom used to cook for me growing up.  "Minced Pork Over rice" dish is called "Lo Bah Bung" in Taiwanese and traditionally comes with a stained hard boiled egg.  

I went at 9 o'clock with my cousin at night (Sunday), we were already a few drinks in and slightly rowdy.   The waiter was very patient with us, and had definitely more than accommodated us.  

We ordered 4 things on the menu: 

Braised Beef Noodle Soup - A lot of flavor in the broth.  Beef melts and is very soft.  Noodles are good. One of the best beef noodles soups I had.  

Pork Blood (Steamed) - This is one of my favorite thing to eat, and they do it well with peanut powder.  It's very chewy, and the pork blood has the flavor (and texture) of a rice cake.  Not for the faint of heart. 

Scallion Pancake w/ fish sauce - My cousin loved this.  It was pretty good.  I'm not sure if they make this in-house or if this is a pre-packaged dish.  

Pepper Steak w/ Noodles - This is like Taiwanese junk food.  I loved that they had it.  Beef was a bit over cooked & dry, but otherwise a fairly good dish.  Can't really do this one wrong. 

One recommendation I have for the restaurant is to add ba wan (traditional Taiwanese meat bun) to the menu (images below). 

Ba Wan's are just waiting to be the new asian craze in the western world, just like Ramen & Soup Dumplings.  

https://www.google.com/search?q=taiwanese+ba+wan&source=lnms&tbm=isch&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjJ26y36efZAhUuwVkKHdaTCcsQ_AUICigB&biw=966&bih=438
author: Justin L.

description: Came here a few days ago with my friend. The most Taiwanese Taiwanese restaurant I've ever seen in the bay. Also, one of the best. They're still at their soft opening, so they'll add more items to their menu later on. They have a really cute snack bar at the front and the candies are for sell. I ordered a grounded pork over rice. It was delicious and the price was reasonable. It was worth my money and will definitely come back to try their beef noodle soup!
author: Tiffany L.

description: HoDaLa means bottoms up in Taiwanese dialect.  It actually happened to the bowl of noodle soup which looked really bland.  the noodles has a really nice smooth crunch that I've never had, and the broth was piping hot and flavorful.  The Pork belly bun was good too.  The pork rice bowl is actually better than the top place we had in Taipei.  We will be back before traveling to Taiwan again.
author: Mei L.

description:
Came here because of the good reviews, left the place disappointed, we got pork belly over rice, ground pork over rice, spicy chicken wings, and mifun.
Pork belly over rice: 2/5, 4 small pieces of pork belly over a lot of rice and veggies, at least put some sauce over the rice. Meat to rice ratio left many rice unfunished.
Ground pork over rice: 4/5, savory saucy and flavorful, the only good dish we got today.
Spicy chicken wings: 3/5, nothing special.
Mifun: 1/5, extremely rigid, easy to break apart noodle (frozen, probably) over watery, blend soup with very few companion ingredients, the worst thing we ordered, for the price of 8 dollars we can get a big hot bowl of beefy pho elsewhere.

The food are easy to make, and most of them are pre-made but it took over 30 to get out food served in a not so busy time. Will not return.
author: Jesse Y.

description: After Yelping a couple of restaurants, I stumbled upon this Taiwanese place--it was conveniently located and close to the Golden Gate Bridge, where my friends and I wanted to go to after lunch. I've got to say...my mood was lifted as I saw the wall with the old school (and semi recent) Jay Chou MVs. Definitely brought back nostalgic moments in early high school. The one dish that I was looking forward to was the tomato beef noodle soup..however that was the one dish that did disappoint. Maybe I have high expectations since my mama has a pretty bomb recipe..but the broth just wasn't super flavorful and the beef was mediocre. However, the other dishes that we did order--pork belly gua bao, ground pork rice (滷肉飯), pork chop over rice (排骨飯), beef wraps (牛肉捲餅), and sweet potato leaves with thousand year old egg (地瓜葉炒皮蛋) were all incredibly tasty and I highly recommend ordering them. Service was also decent--very efficient for only having 2 waitresses. The restaurant was also decorated with Taiwanese 90s toys and candies. Overall, the experience brought back a sense of home for a Taiwanese millennial and had authentic music and delicious food to top it off. Highly recommend for anyone who enjoys Taiwanese music and food! Will be back if I'm ever in the bay area.
author: Jenni W.

description: Small but cute place with wooden banquet seating and old style theater chairs! They have a nice selection on the menu for snacks, appetizers, soup noodles, and meat/rice bowls. We got the beef roll, which was one of the best I've had in the Bay Area, however, you only get 4 small pieces for $8. The broth for the "mai fun" has good depth of flavor and wasn't too salty or oily. The spicy tomato beef noodle soup only had a couple pieces of tomato, but overall hearty for a cloudy cool day. Surprisingly, the "lo rau" rice was our least favorite. Too much vinegar and the pork was a little gamey tasting. Staff was friendly and the food came out pretty quickly.
author: Ellen H.

description:
We love their signature milk tea.   We love the squid and beef noodle.  Their food are very authentic Taiwanese food.   

We would like to see 瓜子肉燥飯 on the new menu
author: Tom Y.

description: We came and ordered fried chicken and Mix Gao Bao. They were both delicious! I think they both should be on the new menu.
author: Paul B.

description: Great for large groups. Good food and really fast service. The Gua Boa was amazing. I would definitely come back here.
author: Justin B.

description: Wandered in here as I noticed it was a new business replacing the chicken noodle place. I ended up ordered the ground pork over rice which is a standard for Taiwanese food as well as the pork belly baos, which I was surprised was 3 per order! The pork bowl was super flavorful and was filling. The baos were very soft and the belly melted in your mouth. It was also topped with a really cool ground peanut mix that added a lot to it. They also had a pretty cool drink menu and a bunch of little tapas I'll have to try when I go back.
author: Zack W.

description: Glad to see someone is trying to make Taiwanese food in the city. The shaved ice was pretty gross. Too sweet with all canned fruits. Nasty. The beef roll was delicious.  The braised pork and pork chop over rice were just ok. Beef noodle soup not memorable. Glad I went once.
author: Fatty A.

description: The place was small for big crowds, but it packed a big flavor punch!! Loved it here ! They were all so nice and accommodating for our large group ! We ordered a variety of dishes and all were super delish ! We will be coming back. !
author: Mel N Viv G.

description: I'm a Taiwanese (born and raised) so when I stepped in the place, I feel home already. There are all the candies that I grew up with and the music videos playing on the wall that you can even hear it in the restroom, literally mimic three set up of cashbox in Taipei (if you've ever been to karaoke in Taipei :)) All the set ups and menu are super authentic and I'd say it's the most Taiwanese place I've been in Bay Area so far. Most of the places I've been are either old Hong-Kongese style or Taiwanese family style; however this place will give you a bit of young vibe :) Food wise, they're definitely good - can't compared to the best in Taiwan but I'd still recommend people come to try, absolutely try all the fruit flavors of Taiwan Beer.
author: Kathie F.

description:
I don't know Taiwanese cuisine but I know what I like. Service was friendly, food was delicious, and ambiance was cool.  Affordable prices too! 

The menu is not huge - that could be an issue over multiple visits. But I'll be back.

And another thing -- we tried to go to Dragon Beaux at 2:52p, they would not seat us because they close at 3:00. We crossed Geary and went to HoDaLa, they were happy to serve us. They also close at 3:00p. Yay for the little guys!
author: jim b.

description: Good place. Got the braised beef rice plate. The noodles are also pretty good too. Would come again.
author: Thomas C.

description: Ordered famous Taiwanese lurou fan. The rice was cold and undercooked. The glasses were super dusty, seem to have been out for over a month. Gave it a few tries in three different occasions in three different times... food was bad. As a Taiwanese, I feel sad for it. The deco is pretty good tho. Reminds me of my childhood.
author: John C.

description: I've been here a few times now and the food and service is consistently great. Love their beef noodle soup and other Taiwanese dishes. Highly recommend!
author: Angela C.

description:
I order fried chicken rice, the rice is hard, not soft at all, I think it's microwave rice. But chicken taste good.
Beef noodle soup is not bad.
thousand egg with vegetables taste fine. BUT I found some pieces of Paper Box in the food!!!!!!
The gave me 10% off in the end. Service is not bad.
author: Ho L.

description: Super nice vibe and feels like traveling in Taipei night market，definitely will come next time！Food presentation is super joyful
author: Sunny X.

description: Feel like eating at home, friendly staff,will go back for different items.  No line,just because it was Warrior game that night.
author: Lan C.

description: Food was ok (not a ton of Taiwanese restaurants nearby to compare this with)...but definitely not kid-friendly. They have a dozen TVs and loud music playing all day.
author: Chelsea S.

description: Really good service.  People love it, there was a line the whole time.  I feel like they should stick to what they are good at.  All the noodle dishes were not very good.  Some ingredients is straight from Costco.  Like how they used Costco fish sticks.  For the price of the food, I expect them to try harder.
author: Nathan H.

description: Young lady was very welcoming and made what I needed happen. Food was fast hot and delicious. But won't honor the instore advertisement to get a free shaved ice when you do the Yelp review. Not good to advertise false information.
author: Tiffany H.

description: Not impressed. I ordered pork chop over rice. The meat and the outside batter separated immediately as I cut it. Cabbage stew was ok. The baos were ok, and the meat inside was super dry. The only I liked was tofu & egg which I can also make it at home...I was hoping I could really like this place but unfortunately I don't I would go again. My go-to taiwanese restaurant is still the one in Pleasanton (Taiwan Cafe) but it's so far!!!!!
author: Yc C.

description: Very cool decor, meant to feel modern but vintage and nostalgic. Nothing mind blowing, but overall the food is good. An excellent addition to the neighborhood. My personal favorites are the pork belly rice, the pork belly buns, and the preserved eggs and potato leaves. Just wish everything was $1 cheaper.
author: Will T.

description: Ordered the pork buns, steamed pork blood cake, chicken steak rice bowl, and beef teppan noodle. The teppan noodle didn't have the runny black pepper sauce like how it's usually served, but the flavor was still OK and all the dishes hit the spot for me! The restaurant is modeled after a traditional Taiwanese grocery store, and is actually stocked with Taiwanese candies and snacks for purchase. I loved the food and environment here, and can't wait to be back again!
author: Yen Ting L.

description: This is a must try, I brought my family here for the soft opening and the food is really good...my daughter loves the fried Mac ' Cheese balls and the Fatty Pork in steamed bun is to die for...it just melts in your mouth, the Taiwanese ground pork over rice is very tasty and it will leave u wanting more, we ordered 4 of the fried items from the pork cutlet to the chicken and it was fried to perfection, don't take my word for it.....try it out and u will definetly be coming back !!!
author: Johnny H.

description: My girlfriend and I ordered the beef wrap, braise beef over rice and the Taiwanese Pork Belly Gua Bao. All three dishes were amazing. We enjoyed the Taiwanese Pork Belly Bao the most. The pork belly was super bomb!!
author: Anthony L.

description:
Love this place! We stopped in on the way to a movie with limited time. Service was excellent, quick and food was insanely delicious. 

Can't wait to come back with more friends!
author: Magan B.

description: I really like the fried pork chop, very cripsy. i also like the fried Tofu( the dip sauce definitely brings to a different level. And it's a very inexpensive place :)
author: Jason J.

description: The best Taiwanese restaurant I've ever been to in the states! Beef noodle and beef pancakes are the must-tries! The milk tea is tasty too! Service is great and the vibe is just perfect. Will come here every week!
author: Lorenzo M.

description:
Super rude and slow service.
Super NOT authentic food.
The rice was NOT even well cooked. 
The chicken was salty like drinking sea water....

What a terrible place
author: Tongtong L.

description: This is probably the worst pork that I ever had~can't even taste it~that's a horrible deep fried pork ~the veggies are half cooked, the rice is cold - maybe that's normal.
author: Eden X.

description: I decided to give this place another try and this time the service was way better. I ordered the combination baos and their beef noodle soup. Everything was amazing.
author: Huyen C.

description:
For some context, I'm Taiwanese. 

Ordered something for delivery, came out to about $45. Tastes alright, but nothing special. Not to mention EXTREMELY small portions. Nowhere near worth what we paid for. When I say small, I mean appetizer-size priced $5 anywhere else that they charge for $10 and up. Super overpriced for what they give you, and they forgot our beverage. I don't know how the experience is when you go in person, but if you're ordering take-out, don't bother.
author: John C.

description: Delicious and authentic Taiwanese food. Can't  be better. We have been here for four times and ordered different food and everything on the menu has been great
author: Jessica C.

description: Its my first time checking out this place with my brother, and its very comfortable sitting here chatting since this place have a nice ambiance. We ordered the Braised Beef Noodle Soup (its REALLY good and perfectly flavored), the (3)GuaBao 刮包 with Pork Belly (my brother took a first bite and was surprised at how good it tasted!), and the Pork Belly over Rice (爌肉飯). I had expected that I would like the 爌肉飯 the most, but it was dry (沒有汁) and kind of salty, and since the portions were pretty big, I had the rest to-go so I can finish it at home for a late-night snack. As for what I'd recommend to the menu, I would recommend some of my favorite Taiwanese foods: 肉圓 & 大腸包小腸. Overall, I really like this place and I'd definitely come back! ^^
author: Amy L.

description: Food is really good! So many more dishes I want to try. Will need to get a big group of friends to come to try more things :D would like to see 蚵仔煎，鱿鱼羹面，大肠面线 on the menu!
author: Siyao X.

description: That is my first time to try Taiwanese food. I ordered is preserved egg with sweet potato leave and beef noodle soup and the taste have killed my tongue. It's so good. The important part is They got reasonable price for the food and very good service.
author: Eddie Z.

description: HoDaLa ("Bottoms Up!) I wandered into this place on Geary by chance. Taiwanese fusion. Super cool ambience with Taiwanese pops Tara (Fan Wei Qi ) screened on the wall, tap beer and kimchee pork belly boa to die for! They have a Taiwanese candy stand. There are cool theater seats and retro light bulbs in minimalist design. And the price point is super reasonable. The wait staff are chill and on top of it.  I'll be back with my friendz.
author: Todd R.

description: As I'm always on the lookout for good Taiwanese food in the city, I was so pleasantly surprised to find HoDaLa! Their minced pork is delicious and closely resembles some of the better minced pork rice I've had in SoCal. Also their pork belly (both over rice and in buns) is simply amazing. The meat is perfectly cooked and just melts in your mouth. You also can't go wrong with the beef noodle soup. Can't recommend this place enough!
author: Megan W.

description:
This is probably my favorite Taiwanese restaurant in the neighborhood. Good decor, good service and food are decently priced. 
Would recommend getting the pork ribs over rice!
author: Bryan L.

description: Excellent and consistent food, with cool music videos playing on the wall. Menu is divided into soups and rice, with comfort food appetizers. Best items: sweet corn with cheese, preserved egg with pork floss and tofu, and beef noodle soup.
author: David M.

description:
I liked this cozy place tucked away on Geary. The sign said soft opening so just take that into account. We got bunch of things-a pitcher of beer, pork guabao, green scallion pancakes, fried meat sticks, braised beef noodle soup, and fried pork chop over rice. There was a little wait when we got there, but somehow they skipped over some parties and took us to a table fairly quickly. The two ladies waiting tables are super nice and kind, which is kinda amazing. I tend to associate Asian restaurants with straight forward service aka North Korean style (just kidding) sans any smiles. The food overall was unfortunately very average and a bit of miss for me. I was totally stoked that another Taiwanese eatery opened up. The guabao was probably the best. The meat was tender and flavors were nice and not over the top like chairman bao's in the tenderloin. The buns were pretty cold or luke warm at best. The pancake was little greasy and chewy.  the fried meat sticks were ok. They are like miniature fried wontons, and not memorable. The pork chop over rice tasted really good but the meat was over cooked and became very stringy. The braised beef noodle soup was similar. The broth was really solid but the meat was very stringy, I had one piece that was tender and rest felt like they were cooked to death. But it was the noodle itself that did me in. They were just flat,
store bought noodles with no texture what so ever. I was hoping that for 12 dollars, I'd get fresh hand made noodles, which ironically a lot of the Asian hotpot places (which line the street) have now. So taking everything into account, I think the prices are a bit high for the quality of food dished out, but good and friendly service. Will probably wait a while until we come back. Hope they put a little more effort into the food and menu itself. Now onto Walgreens to get some floss.
author: Charles L.

description: Hmm... I really did want to love eating the food at this place because they looked so good on Yelp and just from looking on the menu. However, the quality of the food wasn't as I had expected (more on the salty side) for a pretty high price. The bubble milk tea however was very delicious, more on the milky side. I love the design of the place and had friendly customer service.
author: Vivian N.

description: The food is not very good. The staff is friendly. The stadium seats are very uncomfortable. The sauce on the pork belly buns is strange. The fried pork cutlet over rice is ok but not the best. The soup taste is strange.
author: Karl K.

description: This place has a very cute interior and gives a nice homey place. My friend and I came here for late night food and it really hit the spot. They should put basil popcorn chicken on the menu to go with the boba drinks!
author: Michelle K.

description: Great pork belly bao and green onion pancake. We also got a squid noodle which was good.
author: Lisa T.

description: Best gua baos I've had in San Francisco. The Taiwanese food here is very tasty. I'll be coming back here for sure.
author: Vicky C.

description: Service was good and staff friendly. Beef noodle soup definitely not what you would get in Taiwan. It's ok, just not the traditional beef noodle soups. Scallion pancake was overpriced for the what was provided and felt like it may have come from a package. Pork rice was ok.. MSG a bit on the higher side, was thirsty for an hour or so after the meal.
author: B H.

description: I came here on a Sunday night around 5:30 pm and it was not that crowded. We got seated immediately into these uncomfortable old theatre chairs. They are extremely uncomfortable and feel very awkward. The servers brought us the menu and it looked really old and worn out, it was made from paper there was no lamination or anything and the menus smelled bad. We ordered the squid noodle, pork buns, minced pork over rice. The pork buns were pretty good however I can tell the meat was extremely fatty , I didn't like it so I took off the fat from the meat. But the bun is very delicious! And the presentation is the cutest! The minced pork over rice was just ok, I wouldn't order it again. It was not that special. The squid noodle was SO UNBELIEVABLY SALTY!! I could not finish that fish because the noodles were soaked in oil and salt and msg. It was so bad I couldn't eat much of it. The squid was pretty good but really salty as well. The service here is pretty good, all the waiters were pretty friendly. But due to the food and atmosphere I would not come back.
author: Carissa C.

description: What a wonderful edition to the Outer Richmond. This location has been plagued with one failure of a restaurant after another. Not anymore! Food here is amazing and fun. The staff is attentive. And the atmosphere is fun and engaging. Sorry no pictures this time to busy eating right away. Cant wait to go back.
author: Rebecca N.

description: Food is over all too salty. Not too many choices from the menu. However, service is nice. Hope they can make some improvements.
author: Jenny C.

description: I like the fried chicken rice the most. I would love to have 蝦仁煎 and stinky tofu on the new menu.
author: John S.

description:
Horrible Taiwanese place do not go. The services abysmal they don't have enough servers. Actually only have one server.  I had to pick up my own menus. Then they never give me utensils or my plate. 

For the food I would say it is not authentic. The price is OK for San Francisco but overall do not go. They should get their act together otherwise still should close up. I mean they will close up very soon.
author: Alex H.

description:
Generally disappointed. 

We had high hopes for this spot since it was highly rated here and its a rare Taiwanese restaurant in a very Asian neighborhood. Sadly we just weren't at all impressed. 

To be fair, they did have a "Soft opening" sign up so perhaps these are areas they can still tweek and improve on.  

The service: very slow. The restaurant wasn't packed and there was technically no line and yet we still had to wait a while to get seated. Ended up getting seated at the bar. It'll be another while before anyone came to take our order and give us water. And it'll be longer still to actually get the food.  New restaurant though so I guess this is expected. 

The food: We got a few things to share:

"fried chicken" bao
beef rolls
beef noodle soup

I put the fried chicken in quotes because this was as much fried chicken as a McChicken patty... Meaning this wasn't fried chicken at all. It's not even clear whether this was chicken. Basically think of the McChicken sandwich, cut it in half and replace McDonald's bread with a bao then add a little Costco mustard.  Thats the fried chicken bao. The pork belly looked better. We regreted our decision. 

Beef rolls were okay. Slightly on the small side. The beef was very tendony and the wrap was chewy rather than crispy.  Beef noodle soup was good, but not anything to come back or wait for.

The space: Overall well decorated, slightly cheesy with a 80s Taiwan theme. There is a projector that's plays Taiwanese music videos. The most entertaining part though is that the projector was connect to an iPhone and it would also project text messages and incoming phone calls.. amazing.
author: John S.

description:
Got in slightly after opening memorial day, and managed to get a cozy corner seat by the window.

Pork belly gua bao and scallion pancakes for starters were very good! Extra points for the unique presentation of the gua bao.

The beef noodle soup had a pretty generous portion, and the beef was very tender. The broth was very flavorful, but spicier than I remember from trips to Taiwan. Noodles were clearly not fresh made, as some strands were sticking to each other (as can happen with dried noodles).

Service was good, and food came out fast. Overall, definitely a great experience!
author: Darren W.

description: Really authentic Taiwanese atmosphere and menu but the food can be improved. The pork belly bao was the highlight, the ground pork over rice was delicious, but the beef noodle soup had beef that was way too tough and noodles that were clearly store-bought. The fried tofu looked on point but was bland and the sauce tasted store bought. It's definitely the "most Taiwanese" restaurant in authenticity I've been to in SF, and I would return just for that, but I hope to see a more complete menu and definitely a better beef noodle soup recipe. Service was great.
author: Grace B.

description: The flavors are rich yet simple and fresh. Very larger portions--especially of meat. Presentation is nice and clean. Come here when you're looking for Chinese/Taiwan homes style very well done.
author: Anthony B.

description: Food was not executed well.  Tasted like it was from the microwave of a boba shop rather than a sit down restaurant.
author: Paul C.

description: I visited HoDaLa the other day for lunch and I was pretty impressed with the food quality. I tried the stir fried mi fan and it was great. I've tried other Taiwanese restaurants and as a fan of Taiwanese food I could consider this one as one of the best restaurants around. The service was also great and they are always looking after in case you need something. Highly recommended, must try it!!!
author: Armando C.

description: The food is very delicious. It would be perfect if they can have oyster mee sua on the menu.
author: Jay W.

description: This is the worst Taiwanese food in the bay area. I have tried so many different Taiwanese restaurants before, this place has a traditional Taiwanese display in the middle of the restaurant which is great to make people recalled their childhood memories. Service are friendly and nice. Unfortunately, the dishes taste really salty, we ordered their fried noodle with black pepper sauce and the traditional Taiwanese dishes, also their matcha milk tea and we were expecting is going to be amazing taste, but it was not! !! Milk tea taste full of sugar, and noodle taste too salty.I am sorry even the store layout looks very good and attractive, but their food was taste really bad and salty in general. Hope they can get better
author: Leon K.

description:
Pretty good overall!

Ordered:

Braised beef noodle soup - 4.5 Stars, great taste and flavors, a must try here!

Fried chicken w/ rice - 4 Stars super yummy, taste like popcorn chicken

Scallion pancake - 3.5 Stars nothing special but it does come with a unique sauce

Mixed bao - pork belly bao 4.5 Stars sooo good! 
Fried fish bao 2.5 Stars taste like frozen fish
Fried chicken bao 2.5 Stars taste like frozen chicken nuggets, if they changed it to the chicken they used in the rice, it'll be so much better

We ordered milk tea and the black tea with lemon, they were both pretty good!
author: michele h.

description: HoDala is such a cozy restuant where serve delicious Taiwanese food! The beef noodle soup and pork belly bun are just amazing! I had tried different kinds of buns at many restaurants and I can say that HoDala has one of the best in the Bay. Another dish grabed my attention was the noodle with a whole squid serve on top. I never seen something like that! If you are a squid lover, definitely give a try. Overall, it was a good experience. Come and pay a visit, the pork buns wont disappoint you.
author: Dave Z.

description: Tried this place the first time and really like it! The atmosphere is cozy and friendly. Staffs are attentive. My favorite food here is the Mi-Fun soup, the soup is tasty and the noodle has just the right texture. I would like to see they add more Taiwanese night market type of food and pork neck meat steak.
author: Coco C.

description: Good Asian Fusion with a diverse menu. Staff was super friendly and accommodated our large party of 16. I shared the noodle soup, rice dish, tofu, and pork belly with three other friends which were all delicious. Pork belly came in set of three so we had order another one. Would definitely come again.
author: Seaton N.

description: I went there twice.  I like the services there.  The waiter is polite and he chatted with us and took our advice/comments nicely.   Foods are good.  I like their pork belly over rice.  If u aren't afraid of the fat, you must try it.   And I have to mention the decorations of the restaurant.  The owner must have put a lot of heart and effort in it.  The chairs are cool - old movie theater seats.  They also sell candies and snacks in a old-style way (put them in big glass jars).  If you are from Taiwan or Hong Kong, you'll find them amusing.
author: Shirley C.

description: The food was SO good and actually really reasonably priced!  We got the pork buns and the fried mac n cheese balls.  Both were amazing.  Only down side is that it took over an hour for us to be seated and order and eat and get our check, but I understand that they just opened and were super short staffed.  Food was worth the wait!
author: Geena G.

description: I love Taiwanese food but somewhat disappointed.  I would have given 1 star but the service was excellent.   Great atmosphere and the place is very nicely decorated.  However, the food is just so so.  The beef was very tough to chew on and the noodle was too salty .  I'm not sure if this corner space is jinx or not, but whatever restaurant that operates at this location ends up closing.   I hope they survive and I hope the chef read my comments.
author: Lawrence L.

description: Giving a 1 star because on yelp, it's says they're ppen. Got to the restaurant and they were CLOSED!
author: Manny D.

description: Everything was too salty. It made me just trying to finish the dishes for not wasting money. My friend and me needed to drink a lot of water to get rid of that feeling. The worst thing was we even need to eat some candies, too.
author: Crystal T.

description: It's a cool little spot in the Richmond. Lots of small plates to choose from if you just want a snack. They also serve noodle soups and rice bowls if you are hungrier. Will need to come back to the the whole squid surf and turf. Looks promising.
author: Tony L.

description:
Came here on a Sunday night and they were packed (not a large place). The food was decent and I would come back if I was craving Taiwanese food and didn't wana drive to East or South Bay. 

Unfortunately, the service needs work and they are a bit over priced. Having worked in restaurants for years, they need to figure out a better rhythm and a division of labor between their servers (two servers doing everything front of house). It's not great to see the servers fighting with each other; work together! Hope you guys guys can work out your kinks; look forward to coming back and updating this review with more stars!
author: Jessica C.

description: Had to wait 50 min for the surf and turf. But food was excellent. I enjoyed the texture of the wonton noodle and the wontons were yummy. The waiter tries very hard to serve everyone well, but the kitchen seems a little understaffed. My friend loved her surf and turf. I'd come back and try something else.
author: Tamara T.

description:
so, i came here right when it opened and i was very disappointed. 

Beef noodle soup- i ordered beef noodle soup without tomato, yet they gave me a tomato flavor beef noodle soup? noodles were over cooked making it disgusting.

porkchop over rice- the porkchop was extremely greasy and salty. the rice was just decent

rice noodle soup- no flavor. it was like they cooked the noodle and put it in hot water.

squid over noodle(forgot name)- the squid was whole, so therefore it was hard to cut into it. it was also really hard to chew. the noodle also had no flavor and was really soft

the milk tea- so sweet i could get sugar high

gua bao- was so cold when we ate it. compared to taiwan's gua bao...i was no where neared impressed

We ordered all of these and came out with an amount of 80$ with a tip of 10$. 
will not come here ever again.
author: Evelyn H.

description: Best Taiwanese food in Sf in my opinion! Beef noodle soup was spot on with a bit of spice in broth. Beef roll was amazing, fried chicken over rice was bomb, I could go on and on. Please go! The decorations also remind me of Taiwan so much-- my friend and I basically ordered the whole menu cuz it was that good!
author: Sophia L.

description: HoDaLa is a casual dining option in the neighborhood to grab a quick bite of food with unique Taiwanese favor.
author: Pedro R.

description: Definitely satisfied my cravings for Taiwanese food! We got the ground pork over rice, braised beef noodle soup, and pork belly gua bao. There was less than expected ground pork but still pretty good. Braised beef could be more tender but the soup was decent. Gua bao was
author: Felicia L.

description: Taiwan numba 1!!!! Great food and service. Order the pork chop over rice and milk tea.
author: Kevin L.

description: Food was great! Ordered the noodles with whole squid as well as the sweet potato leaves - both delicious. Just wish the veggie portion was a little larger, overall a nice spot for lunch! Our friends ordered the beef noodle soup, beef pancake roll, and pork belly buns. All really good. For the pork belly buns, they sprinkle them with a peanut sugar, which made them really yummy.
author: Anna W.

description: The sizzling beef noodle plate is to die for. Our server Eddy was so nice and attentive. Will definitely come back, love the environment. Also a fan of the lychee beer! Cheers helpers
author: Crystal M.

description: I visited Hodala yesterday. Although they are still soft opening,it was the best Taiwanese restaurant I have ever been to! They serve real traditional Taiwanese food with a reasonable price. Plus they decorate the restaurant really well, dining there was like eating in Taipei. If you really like Taiwanese food or post pictures on social media, this place is perfect for you! (There's a promotion of 10% off for dining in untill 2/28)
author: Hope C.

description: Best described as Taiwanese street food. I tried the three buns combination. The pork belly was wayyyy too salty and overwhelmed everything. The fish fillet (literally; on a bun) tasted like microwaveable fish sticks. Chicken fillet tasted like mc chicken on a Bun, also tasted microwaved. The meat lover was nothing special aside from the 19$. Noodles were overly dressed in sauce, sausage was different( in a bad way), steak was alright nothing special. The fried pork chop was actually not bad but I wouldn't go back for it. Overall 2 stars. Overly seasoned. Decent customer service.
author: Jimmy C.

description: Omg best beef noodles I ever had in SF. They also serve a variety of desserts and small bites that from Taiwan. Super authentic and great value! Also, they're currently having BOGO BEER!!
author: Dax T.

description: The sizzling beef noodle plate is to die for. Our server Eddy was so nice and attentive. Will definitely come back, love the environment. Also, a fan of the Taiwanese Passion Fruit beer! Cheers, yelpers!
author: Adriana C.

description: Nice place! remind me how good the Taiwanese food is! Also it's an awesome place for taking pictures and for a meal. I ordered the beef noodle soup and it tasted just like the original ones in Taiwan. Also tried the pork belly bao, highly recommend this one!
author: Jimmy W.

description: Great place for Taiwai food. The milk tea is awesome.
author: Tianhui W.

description: This place has a lot of MSG. Very thirsty from eating the Porkchop over rice
author: Jennifer T.

description: With few decent Taiwanese authentic dishes, but some others were just OK.  The beef noodle soup was way too salty for me.  Giving three stars for reasonable prices.
author: Jess M.

description: amazing gua bao！ both spicy and traditional Bao Zi are tasty. And the rice noodle soup has rich flavor in soup so every sip of noodle is with the flavor. The store has a vintage style decoration. It feels like go to a snack store in he neighborhood. Amazing ambience.
author: B Y.

description: To the restaurant owner: big mistake putting in that gigantic counter. Takes up too much real estate which you're not making $$ on. Get rid of that candy clutter.  You're not selling $1 candy, you need to sell tables.  On a busy Sat night with a good line of customers on the wait list, that counter space is completely wasted when no one sits there and when you could have placed tables instead. Improve your speed of service to turn tables faster.  You're missing out on $$.
author: Judy H.

description:
rice noodle was good
pork belly over rice was a bit salty
gua bao was good
author: Diane W.

description: Food is not that special but the view and atmosphere is really great. If you want small snack with a beer, here is the place to look for. The service here is really nice. Even though you are on the waiting list, but the waiter really pay attention to you, he will ask if you need water or anything he can help when you are waiting.
author: Vi N.

description: Being a big Taiwanese food fan. Knowing there's a new Taiwanese restaurant opened in San Francisco is definitely a good news in my mind! After reading all the raving reviews on yelp! I decided to check this place out! The theme of the restaurant definitely reminds me of the 80s, which is similar to the theme set from class of 302 down in LA. Due to soft opening, the menu is limited, I didn't see anything Taiwanese dessert such as snow ice or boba drinks. I ordered the potato leafs, beef noodle and mi fun! My first sip of the beef noodle soup def reminds me of spicy bean paste, soup itself is bland and noodle isn't the typical fresh noodle you find in Taiwan! Overall, I will say the beef is tender but still chewy. 3 out of 5 and definitely something I will not order. As for mi fun, it reminds me of instant noodle soup packet mix with hot water, add mushroom, green onion and rice noodle! Bland and not flavorful! Lastly, the potato leaf is actually very good. But overall, I was disappointed! I guess I will continue to drive down to South Bay whenever I crave for Taiwanese food.
author: Aaron L.

description: The main reason for the 3 stars is that the braised beef meat was too tough to chew. Otherwise the food was pretty tasty. Lots of flavor.
author: Jc B.

description: From the perspective of a Taiwanese American, this place is awesome.  Pretty authentic (I didn't try the fried mac and cheese balls, or other fusiony items  on the menu).  The minced pork rice and gua bao are pretty darn good. Good flavor for the beef noodle soup, but the scallion pancakes were nothing special. I also liked their green tea, although I'm sure they're going to get a lot of questions on where the tapioca is because you'd think a Taiwanese restaurant with an extensive tea drinks menu would have bubble tea.  Clean, cute decor, and great service.  This is the best Taiwanese food I've had in SF, and maybe the entire Bay Area.  Highly recommended!!!
author: Rob L.

description: Great food, excellent customer service from the young man working there. Pork buns are great and recommend the Sao bun with Taro Ice cream. Moreover, the wait can get a little long since it is a smaller place, however it is worth the wait. Prices is reasonable and the beers are good also. All and all 5 out of 5.
author: Jean-Carlo D.

description: ordered the pork belly bun and was excellent.  also ordered beef stew noodle and ground pork over rice.  they were very good also.
author: Phillip L.

description: Never been to Taiwanese Restaurant before but in love with the food they have!! The quality of food and Service are amazing. Highly recommend to those who live in the Bay :)
author: Na Gyeong L.

description: YUM. We came here for the first time on a Saturday night for take out (and thank goodness we did because the line for dine in was massive), and the food was so good we came back the next day for a round 2. I've had both the tomato beef noodle soup and the braised beef noodle soup, and prefer the braised beef. Both soups are very similar, however, and the texture of the noodles was spot on. The braised beef soup definitely has a spicy kick to it which I loved. We loved their yam leaves dish as well. The pork belly rice bowl was a bit lacking, but decent. I wish there were more veggie options on the menu (I think yam leaves was the only veggie dish if I recall...). I wish the restaurant fit more people (is the center table/bar really necessary to sell $1 candies?) But overall, very happy with the addition of this Taiwanese restaurant to the neighborhood, and we hope it sticks around! (Especially given that previous restaurants in that same location fail every few years :( )
author: Sophia L.
